node.title: Cosmological Argument (2012)
node.videosynopsis: William Lane Craig has worked extensively on a version of the cosmological argument called the Kalam cosmological argument. While the Kalam has a venerable history in medieval Islamic philosophy, Craig updated the argument to interact with contemporary scientific and philosophical developments, which he outlines in this video.

node.title: Nietzche's critique of Christianity
node.videosynopsis: Stephen N Williams explores Nietzche's critique of Christianity by seeking to uncover the reasons and background behind the critique.

node.title: The Theological Development & Major Works of Anthony Thiselton
node.videosynopsis: Anthony Thiselton describes how he become interested in hermeneutics and the major works that resulted.

node.title: The life, works and influence of Thomas Aquinas
node.videosynopsis: Franklin T Harkins discusses the life, works and influence of Thomas Aquinas.

node.title: The life, works and influence of Augustine or Hippo (Part 1 of 2)
node.videosynopsis: Janet Soskice discusses the life, works and influence of Augustine of Hippo (Part 1 of 2)

node.title: The life, works and influence of Augustine or Hippo (Part 2 of 2)
node.videosynopsis: Janet Soskice discusses the life, works and influence of Augustine of Hippo (Part 2 of 2)

node.title: The life and works of Balthsar
node.videosynopsis: Karen Kilby discusses the life and works of Balthsar

node.title: The life, works and influence of Barth
node.videosynopsis: David Clough discusses the life, works and influence of Barth

node.title: Theological Aesthetics and Art
node.videosynopsis: Ben Quash unpacks Theological Aesthetics by exploring its roots, its time in the wilderness, its resurgence as a relevant theological study in the 20th century and its depiction through art.

node.title: Balthasar's trilogy of works starting with Theological Aesthetics
node.videosynopsis: Karen Kirby explains Balthasar's thinking for his trilogy of works where he starts with Theological Aesthetics, followed by Theo-Drama, leading to Theo-Logic.

node.title: The life, works, influence and death of Dietrich Bonhoeffer
node.videosynopsis: Tom Greggs discusses how Bonhoeffer's theology shaped his life and created incredible inner searching during the 2nd World War as he smuggled Jews out of Germany and opposed Hitler's regime.

node.title: Moltmans theological orientation towards hope for the future within life in the present.
node.videosynopsis: Richard Bauckham discusses Moltmans theological orientation towards hope for the future whilst fully recognising the reality of this in living the Christian life.

node.title: Bultmann's theological journey
node.videosynopsis: David Fergusson describes Bultmann's theological journey from his liberal training through to Baltmann's assertion that the only critical element of the life of Jesus is the crucifixion, which left some significant weaknesses in his arguments.

node.title: The life, works and influence of Joseph Butler
node.videosynopsis: Christopher Cunliffe discusses the life, works and influence of Joseph Butler highlighting his focus on moral philosophy and theological application to everyday life.

node.title: The life, works and influence of John Calvin
node.videosynopsis: Tony Lane discusses the life, works, theology and influence of Calvin as a second generation reformist.

node.title: The life of Charles Darwin and his development of the theory of evolution by natural selection
node.videosynopsis: Nick Spencer discusses the life of Charles Darwin and how he moved away from Christianity as he developed his theory of evolution by natural selection

node.title: Modern Theology
node.videosynopsis: David Ford discusses the way that theology has developed significantly over the past 100 years

node.title: An analysis of Dawkin's assumptions
node.videosynopsis: William Lane Craig discusses the assumptions that Dawkin's has used

node.title: Jacques Derrida's 'Deconstruction' philosophical strategy
node.videosynopsis: Steven Shakespeare discusses Jacques Derrida's 'Deconstruction' philosophical strategy for reading a text with an ear to what runs counter to the intended meaning or structural unity of a particular text.

node.title: Jacques Derrida's Religious Motifs
node.videosynopsis: Steven Shakespeare discusses Jacques Derrida's 'Religious Motifs' and how he avoids making doctrinal commitment whilst recognising the 'otherness' of God

node.title: The theology of Jacques Derrida
node.videosynopsis: Steven Shakespeare discusses how Jacques Derrida, a 20th century philosopher, has developed his theology

node.title: Introduction to Rene Descarte and his mathematically rooted philosophy
node.videosynopsis: John Cottingham discusses Rene Descartes and his rationalist approach to philosophy where he asserts that mathematical rules were established by the supreme being, God, therefore they can be used as a basis for philosophical reason

node.title: Rene Descarte's Legacy and Rationalism
node.videosynopsis: John Cottingham discusses the legacy of Rene Descartes

node.title: Romanticism and Samuel Taylor Coleridge
node.videosynopsis: Douglas Hedley discusses Romanticism as it emerges from Enlightenment and the live and theology of the Philosopher Samuel Taylor Coleridge

node.title: An understanding of Enlightenment
node.videosynopsis: Peter Harrison discusses the various understandings that historians have given to Enlightenment by exploring the different focuses across France, England, Scotland and Germany. He discusses the various characteristics of Enlightenment and how it progressed the view of religion through rationalism and experience but also how it gave social legitimacy to science

node.title: The distinctive characteristics of Evangelicalism and its growth
node.videosynopsis: David Hilborn discusses the distinctive characteristics of Evangelicalism and its origins and growth. He explores the importance of the Protestant Reformation, Puritanism, Pietism and the religious revivals

node.title: Jesus and the Eye Witnesses
node.videosynopsis: Richard Bauckham discusses the importance of the testimony of eyewitness within the writing of the gospels and the audience that they were written for. He highlights the differences between oral history and oral tradition and the issues of fact and interpretation.

node.title: Exploration of the Faith verses Reason argument
node.videosynopsis: Tim Hull explores the Faith verses Reason argument by discussing the augment from early philosophers to present day thinking by principally referring to Plato's image of someone emerging from a cave.

node.title: The views of Gadamer
node.videosynopsis: Anthony Thiselton discusses Gadamer's views on art & science and rationalism and abstractism

node.title: The scientific revolution of the Middle Ages and Galileo's contribution
node.videosynopsis: James Hannam discusses the Scientific Revolution that happened during the Middle Ages and the contribution that Galileo made, and the Church's resistance, in trying to progress the assertions of Nicolaus Copernicus, a Renaissance-era mathematician and astronomer who formulated a model of the universe that the earth revolved around the sun and visa versa.

node.title: The life and works of Stanley Hauerwas
node.videosynopsis: Darren Sarisky discusses the life of Stanley Hauerwas, his approach to theology and his prolific writings.

node.title: The life, works and influence of Hans Wilhelm Frei
node.videosynopsis: Ben Fulford discusses Hans Wilhelm Frei's approach to biblical hermeneutics and its emphasis on facilitating the shaping of ones life in conformity with God's action in history.

node.title: The philosophical views of Hegel
node.videosynopsis: Andrew Shanks discusses the thoughts of philosopher Georg Wilhelm Friedrick Hegel and the key influencers of his critical thinking at a time when there was prolific output of varying philosophical views in Germany.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts and works of Heidegger
node.videosynopsis: George Pattison discusses the philosophical thoughts and works of Martin Heidegger.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts and works of John Hick - Part 1 of 2
node.videosynopsis: David Cheetham starts his discussion on the philosophical thoughts and works of John Hick in this part 1 of 2.

node.title: The 'Old Quest' for the Historical Jesus
node.videosynopsis: Clive Marsh discusses the 'Old Quest', 1778-1914, for the Historical Jesus by exploring the works that were written on the subject during that time and the historical and theological interpretations that had been presented.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts and works of David Hume
node.videosynopsis: David Fergusson discusses the thought and works of David Hume, an agnostic, who has a sceptical philosophical approach, having abandoned a religious life in his mid-teens.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts and works of John Hick - Part 2 of 2
node.videosynopsis: David Cheetham concludes his discussion on the philosophical thoughts and works of John Hick in this part 2 of 2.

node.title: The thoughts and works of John Locke
node.videosynopsis: John Perry discusses the thoughts and works of John Locke trough the three questions that Locke endeavours to address: What should I believe? (Epistemology) What should I do? (Ethics) and How should we live together? (Politics).

node.title: The philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant - Part 1 of 2
node.videosynopsis: Christopher Insole starts his discussion on the philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant in this part 1 of 2.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant - Part 2 of 2
node.videosynopsis: Christopher Insole continues his discussion on the philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant in this part 2 of 2.

node.title: The theological thoughts of Karl Barth
node.videosynopsis: David Clough discusses the theological thoughts of Karl Barth and how he had moved to a position of placing God's revelation of Christ as the starting point.

node.title: The theological and philosophical thoughts of Karl Rahner
node.videosynopsis: Karen Kilby discusses the philosophical and theological thoughts of Karl Rahner, a German Jesuit Priest and Theologian.

node.title: The psychoanalytical philosophy of Jacques Lacan
node.videosynopsis: Marcus Pound discusses how Jacques Lacan took the psychoanalyst thoughts of Fraud and developed them by establishing an approach that saw the unconscious structured like a language.

node.title: The theological thoughts of Martin Luther - Part 1 of 2
node.videosynopsis: Alec Ryrie discusses the theological thoughts of Martin Luther in respect of the 'Nature of Salvation' and his controversial interaction with the established Church in this part 1 of 2.

node.title: The theological thoughts of Martin Luther - Part 2 of 2
node.videosynopsis: Alec Ryrie discusses the theological thoughts of Martin Luther in respect of the 'Nature of Salvation' and his controversial interaction with the established Church in this part 2 of 2.

node.title: The philosophical thoughts of Jean-François Lyotard
node.videosynopsis: Anthony Thiselton discusses the philosophical thoughts of Jean-François Lyotard highlighting his differend approach.

node.title: The theories of Karl Marx
node.videosynopsis: Christopher Britten gives a detailed understanding of the theories of Karl Marx and the people who influenced his thinking.

node.title: Miracles and human misconceptions
node.videosynopsis: Tim Hull discusses the relevance of miracles and the human misconceptions that surround the existence of them

node.title: Moltmann 2
node.videosynopsis: Bauckham discuses Moltmann

node.title: New perspective on Paul
node.videosynopsis: Tom Wright

node.title: John Henry Newman
node.videosynopsis: John Henry Newman by Revd Dr John Davies

node.title: Nouvelle Theology, Henri de Lubac and Radical Othodoxy
node.videosynopsis: Nouvelle Theologie

node.title: Onto Theology Constitution of Metaphysics 1957
node.videosynopsis: Onto theology 1957

node.title: Jesus God and Man, Wolfhart Pannenberg
node.videosynopsis: Jesus God and Man, Wolfhart Pannenberg Christiology
